fable2: A donkey lived on a farm with other animals. One day the farmer opened the gate to the pasture. The other animals went out to graze, but the donkey refused to leave the stable. "Come out and eat some fresh grass!" the sheep bleated. "No, I don't feel like it," the donkey brayed. The other animals enjoyed the sunshine and green grass. The donkey stayed stubbornly in his stall, eating only dry hay. That evening he complained to the other animals how hungry he was. But they just said "You should have come out to the pasture with us."

fable1: When he first encountered a camel, the man was frightened by his size and quickly ran away. After a while, he noticed that the animal was exceptionally gentle and did not wish him any harm, and summoned enough courage to finally approach him. Marvelling at how placid and passive the camel was, the man eventually put a bridle in his mouth and let children ride around on his back.
fable2: A young girl was afraid of the dark woods behind her house. She dreaded walking through them to visit her grandmother. One day she gathered her courage and ventured into the woods with her faithful dog by her side. Though scared at first, the more she walked the path, the less frightening the woods became. Soon the girl was happily running through the woods without a care, her previous dread conquered by use. She arrived at her grandmother's house faster than ever before, rewarded for facing her fears.

fable1: During a siege on their city, the inhabitants assembled to find the best way of protecting themselves against the enemyâ€™s attacks. A brick maker fully believed bricks to provide the most protection and thus recommended a brick wall. A carpenter, equally convinced to be in the right, recommended the use of timber, instead. Finally, a tanner stood up and proclaimed that he disagrees with his fellow townspeople and that leather and hides alone provide superior protection.
fable2: A group of mice lived together in a large field. One day, a cat wandered into their field. The mice panicked and began running in all directions to find places to hide. One mouse found a small hole and squeezed inside where the cat could not reach him. Another mouse tried to run up a tree, but the cat caught him before he could climb to safety. A third mouse ran as fast as he could across the field, but the cat quickly chased him down. In the end, the only mouse who survived was the one who found a hiding spot for himself alone. The other mice were not so lucky.

fable1: On a warm winterâ€™s day, the ants were busy drying corn that they had collected during summer. While they were engaged in their work, a starving grasshopper passed by and begged them for a single grain to stop his hunger. The ants, in turn, asked him why he had not collected food during the summer to prepare for the harsh winter, to which the grasshopper replied that he spent the warm days singing. Mockingly, the ants said to him in unison: "Since you spent your summer singing, then you must dance hungrily to bed in winter."
fable2: A diligent ant worked all summer gathering food for the winter while a grasshopper played and sang. When the first frost came, the grasshopper had nothing saved and was starving. He begged the ant to share his store of food. The ant replied "I worked hard and saved all summer while you wasted your time having fun. You should have prepared for winter like I did." Though the ant had plenty, he refused to share. The grasshopper had no choice but to go hungry.

fable1: A farmer was travelling to the market with a heavily laden donkey and mule. While traversing a plain, both animals carried their load without issue, but as soon as they started climbing a mountain path, the donkey felt that his load was too heavy for him to bear. Struggling, he asked the mule to take over a small part of his load, since he was the stronger of the two, but the mule ignored his plea. Soon enough, the donkey collapsed under the weight and perished. Not knowing what else to do, the farmer placed the entirety of the donkeyâ€™s load onto the mule, in addition to his own, as well as the donkeyâ€™s hide that the farmer intended to sell at their destination. The mule groaned under the extreme weight, regretting not having helped the donkey in the first place.
fable2: A farmer tended to his crops each day. One morning he noticed some pests eating the leaves. He thought about getting pesticide to stop them. But he decided it wasn't a big problem yet. Over the next week, the pests multiplied rapidly. Soon the farmer's entire crop was being devoured. He rushed to get pesticide to kill the pests. But it was too late - the damage was already done. If only he had acted sooner to prevent the infestation from spreading.

fable1: A rooster found a shiny gem while pecking around in the dirt to find food for himself and his hens. Looking down at the stone, he observed: "Had your owner found you, he would have picked you up and treasured you. I, however, have no use for you and would have preferred to find some corn, instead. "
fable2: A poor farmer was walking through the forest when he stumbled upon a large, uncut diamond. He picked it up and examined it, but could not understand its value. "This useless rock is taking up space in my pack," he said. So when he came upon a jeweler's cart, he gladly traded the 'worthless' stone for a simple copper coin. Later that day, the jeweler nearly fainted when he realized what the farmer had traded away - a precious diamond worth enough to feed a village for years. Meanwhile, the ignorant farmer continued on his way, unaware of the fortune he had held in his hands.

fable1: Looking at his mother, a young fawn couldnâ€™t help but ask: "Mother, you are larger, faster, and have more endurance than any of the huntersâ€™ hounds. You can also defend us with your horns. Why is it then, that the dogs frighten you this much?" Her mother replied with a sad smile: " What you are saying is certainly true - I do have all of these advantages. However, as soon as I hear a dogâ€™s bark, I feel the need to flee as I may faint, otherwise."
fable2: A young hare was always afraid of everything. The other animals tried to give him courage. The fox told him scary stories to make him braver. The bear growled loudly so he would not fear strange noises. The eagle flew him high in the sky so he would enjoy great heights. But nothing worked to make the timid hare less afraid. He quivered at the slightest sound and ran from the tiniest creature. The animals finally realized the hare would always be a coward, for no argument can give courage to those who lack it within.

fable1: A coyote had one day found a sheepskin and decided to disguise himself to get easier access to the shepherdâ€™s flock. Covered by the skin, he grazed together with the sheep and snuck into their enclosure in the evening, which was locked and secured by the shepherd. Just as the coyote was preparing to dine on the defenseless creatures, the shepherd returned to obtain some meat for the next day and, confusing the coyote for a sheep, slaughtered him there and then.
fable2: A fox stumbled upon a den of sleeping rabbits. Gleefully, he crept up to the den entrance, licking his chops in anticipation of the feast to come. But the fox was careless, snapping a twig under his paw which awoke the rabbits. Startled, they burst from their den in a flurry and stampeded the fox, kicking him with their powerful hind legs as they fled. Bruised and battered, the fox limped away hungry. He had thought to find an easy meal, but through his own greed and carelessness, ended up bringing harm upon himself instead.

fable1: The silkworm received an order for twenty yards of her finest silk from the tigress and, aiming to finish the order as soon as possible, started working at her loom. Some time later, a spider stopped by and wanted to rent a web-room nearby, to which the silkworm agreed. The spider started working on her own project and was soon finished. Observing the methodical labor of the silkworm, the spider remarked, as she was leaving: "Look at how great and delicate my webs are! And it took me a fraction of the time to spin them that it would have taken you. You must admit that Iâ€™m a much better worker than you could ever be." The silkworm replied: "Be quiet - youâ€™re distracting me. In the end, your webs are nothing more than basic traps, destroyed and brushed away as useless dirt whenever they are seen. In contrast, the fruits of my labor are treasured by royalty all over the world."
fable2: A young painter lived in a small village. Each day he carefully mixed his paints and chose his brightest colors. The painter spent hours crafting beautiful paintings that made people smile. His joyful works filled the village with color and light. Years passed, and the painter grew old. His hands trembled too much to hold a brush. But the vibrant paintings lived on, continuing to delight young and old. The colors never faded, and the images never failed to inspire. Though the painter was gone, his legacy of beauty and meaning endured.

fable1: One evening, the shepherd noticed that one of the rams was missing from his flock. Soon he spotted the ram grazing in the distance and tried to get his attention by whistling and shouting, without success. Finally, he threw a stone at the ram, and hit one of his horns, which shattered on impact. Terrified, the shepherd pleaded with the ram not to tell his master what happened, but the ram replied that his horn will speak for itself, even if he remains silent.
fable2: A fox caught a plump hen and hurried home, eager for his meal. He tried to sneak by a sleeping old hound without waking him. Though the fox tread lightly, the scent of the hen drifted towards the hound. His nose twitched, rousing him from slumber. The hound's eyes opened and spotted the fox creeping by. He leapt up and gave chase. The fox ran as fast as he could, but could not escape the hound following his nose. Outmatched, the fox surrendered his prize to the victorious hound. Moral: Some things cannot be concealed from those determined to find them.

fable1: A rooster was perching on top of a house when he spotted a coyote walk the street below him. Knowing that the coyote wouldnâ€™t be able to reach him, he attacked him with words: "How dare you show yourself so close to the homes of honest people? They all know of your many crimes, you murderer and thief!" Smiling, the coyote replied: "Why donâ€™t you come down here and repeat your accusations to my face?"
fable2: The fox peered out from the bushes at the farmer working in the field. "What a fool, toiling away in the hot sun!" the fox chuckled to himself. "If I were him, I'd lounge in the shade all day." Just then, the farmer headed inside for a break. The fox seized his chance and darted into the chicken coop to steal eggs. But the farmer heard the commotion and ran out waving his rake. The fox scrambled away, empty-pawed and angry. "That farmer is the real fool," the fox huffed. "He'll be sorry he crossed me!"

fable1: While watching his donkey graze in a meadow, the farmer was alerted by what sounded like the cries of an invading force coming from the distance. Alarmed, he told his donkey that they have to flee right away, to which the animal replied: "Why should I flee with you? Do you believe that the enemy will load twice as many bags on my back than you already do?" "No, probably not.", admitted the farmer. "Then, what difference does it make to me whose bags Iâ€™m carrying?", said the animal.
fable2: The kingdom had suffered under the cruel rule of the tyrant king for many years. Finally, the people rose up and overthrew him. They celebrated their new freedom and elected a kind new leader. At first, all seemed well - the new king promised reforms. But soon it became clear he was just as self-serving as the last. He taxed the peasants harshly while living lavishly himself. The poor still struggled as before, their lives no better than under the tyrant. Meet the new boss, same as the old boss.

fable1: A raccoon stumbled by chance into the store room of a theatre. Wandering around, he was suddenly confronted by a face that glared at him from above. Impressed by its beauty, he soon realized that it was just a mask commonly worn by actors during their performances and said: "Although youâ€™re beautiful, itâ€™s a shame that you donâ€™t have any brains."
fable2: The peacock strutted around the farm, fanning his brilliant feathers to impress the other animals. The plain brown sparrow watched quietly from the rafters. When a storm rolled in, the peacock ran for cover, afraid his feathers would be ruined. The sparrow flew out and gathered food for the other animals, then took shelter under a leaf when the rain came. The next day, the peacock emerged bedraggled and forlorn. The sparrow greeted the sunrise with cheerful song. The peacock realized that true beauty comes from within.

fable1: One day, the lion went hunting together with the fox, the coyote, and the weasel. They hunted all day long, until eventually they ambushed a moose and quickly subdued him. The lion then demanded that the stagâ€™s body be divided into four parts, which the other animals quickly accomplished. Standing in front of the individual portions of meat, the lion began to assign the portions as he saw fit. The first portion he gave to himself, since he was the king of all animals. The second portion he also claimed for himself, for his role as the judge dividing the spoils. The third portion he assigned to himself also, for doing his part in the hunt. Finally, he dared the other animals to object to his decision to keep the final portion to himself, as well, yet none was brave enough to do so.
fable2: The lion led the hunt, tracking through the tall grass with the pack close behind. Together they ran down an antelope and made the kill. As the lion began to feed, the jackal approached, seeking his share. But the lion roared and chased him away. Though the jackal had worked as hard as the rest, the lion claimed the meat for himself. The jackal slunk away, hungry. He learned that day to never expect an equal share from the mighty. While he could join the hunt, only the strong take the spoils.

fable1: A king had a son, who liked to hunt wild beasts. One night, the king dreamt that his son would be killed by a tiger and, afraid that the dream was a prophecy, he built for his son a palace which the prince was not allowed to leave under any circumstances. For the princeâ€™s amusement, the walls of the castle were painted with murals depicting life-size animals, including a ferocious tiger.  When the young prince spotted the tiger, he was reminded that he may never set foot outside the castle again, all because of a dream in which he fell to a tiger just like the one in the mural. Enraged, he reached for the branch of a nearby tree, to use it as a club with which he could destroy the mural. But, in doing so, he cut his finder on one of theeâ€™s many thorns. The wound caused him great pain and eventually became inflamed, causing the prince to faint. He soon developed a fever and died only a few days later.
fable2: A young bird fell from its nest before it could fly. It landed on the ground with a thud, its wing bent at an odd angle. The mother bird looked down anxiously from the nest above. "Don't give up!" she called encouragingly. The young bird struggled to its feet. Though its wing hurt terribly, it was determined to be brave. Hop by hop, it made its way up the tree trunk. At last, it reached its mother's waiting wings in the nest. With time and care, its wing would heal.

fable1: A thief had to rent a room at an inn one day and stayed for some time, hoping to steal something that would help him settle the bill. Eventually, he noticed that the innkeeper was wearing a new, fancy coat that would undoubtedly fetch a good price. So the thief sat down with the innkeeper and engaged him in conversation. After some time, he yawned in an exaggerated fashion and howled like a wolf. Surprised, the innkeeper inquired why he would do such a thing. The thief replied: "I will tell you, but youâ€™ll have to hold my clothes or I will tear them to pieces. Iâ€™m not sure when I started yawning like this or what caused this change in behavior, I only know that when I yawn three times in a row, I will turn into a wolf and attack anyone in sight." Once he said this, he immediately yawned and howled a second time. The innkeeper looked visibly alarmed and, planning to run away from the thief, started to stand up. Noticing this, the thief put a hand on the innkeeperâ€™s coat and asked him to stay a while longer to hold his clothes, so that they wonâ€™t get torn when he transforms into a wolf. Just as he was saying this, the thief yawned a third time and howled in a particularly terrifying manner. This scared the innkeeper greatly and, shrugging off his coat to escape the thief's grip, he ran away as fast as he could. The thief, happy with this outcome, took the coat and left the inn never to return.
fable2: A young boy was tending his flock of sheep one sunny afternoon. An old man approached and warned the boy that a ferocious wolf was lurking nearby. The boy became frightened and quickly herded his sheep to safety. Just then, the village trickster emerged from the bushes laughing. He had disguised himself as the old man to play a trick on the boy. From then on, the boy did not believe every warning he heard, even if it seemed real. He knew tales were not always what they appeared to be at first.

fable1: Two toads lived as neighbors in a pond. During a particularly hot summer, the pond dried up and the toads had to find another place to live, as they liked wet places. In their search for a new home, they came across a well with plenty of water in it. Recognizing it as a nice, cool place to live in, one of the toads suggested to his companion that they jump in and make it their new home. The other one, who was older and wiser, replied: "Wait, friend! If the well dried out like our pond did, how would we get out again?"
fable2: An eager young frog was hopping through the forest when he came upon a pond. Seeing the still water, he decided it was the perfect place to take a leap. Without pausing to look carefully, the frog jumped with all his might. But the pond was much shallower than it appeared. The frog landed with a smack on the muddy bottom. Dazed, he slowly swam back to the surface. The other frogs laughed as he crawled onto the bank covered in mud. From then on, that frog took more care when choosing where to jump. Though bruised and embarrassed, he was wiser for the experience.

fable1: The oxen was plowing his ownerâ€™s fields when a pig walked up to him and started pitying the oxen for his endless toils while bragging about her own life of contentment and luxury. Shortly afterwards, the oxen was allowed to rest with the commencement of the annual harvest festival, while the pig was caught and bound with rope by her owner. She was to be sacrificed at the altar to ensure a bountiful harvest. Seeing this, the oxen said to the pig: "It seems that you were only allowed to live an idle life to end up a sacrifice."
fable2: The farm animals decided to have a joke telling contest. The pig told a silly joke and all the animals laughed loudly. The cow told a joke but no one laughed. The chicken clucked out a joke, and the animals giggled politely. When it was the donkey's turn, he told a very funny joke that had all the animals roaring with laughter. The donkey smiled, happy that he was able to make everyone laugh the hardest. Though the pig thought his joke was the funniest, in the end it was the donkey who laughed best by making the animals laugh last.

fable1: A young farmer was carrying two buckets filled with milk from the field to her house and began thinking about the future. "Selling this milk will allow me to purchase approximately three hundred eggs. I can reasonably expect two hundred and fifty chickens to hatch from them, who could then be sold when poultry is most in demand. The profits would allow me to buy a beautiful dress by the end of the year which I could wear to fancy Christmas parties. There, I will likely attract the attention of many eligible bachelors. But I will refuse every one of them, tossing my head like so." When she tossed her head to play out the hypothetical scenario, she dropped the buckets, spilling the milk all over the ground and causing her future plans to crumble.
fable2: Farmer Joe was eagerly awaiting the hatching of his chicken eggs. He imagined how big his flock would grow and all the money he would make selling eggs and chicken meat. Joe started spending the money in his head, buying new equipment for the farm and fancy clothes for his family. When the big day came, Joe rushed out to the coop to welcome the new chicks. But when he got there, he found that most of the eggs hadn't hatched at all! Joe learned an important lesson - it's unwise to make plans based on things that haven't happened yet.

fable1: An old man, suffering from various age-related afflictions, was collecting sticks in the forest to heat his home with. The work was hard and tedious, so eventually he threw down the sticks and cried out that he would rather be dead than endure this hardship any longer. As he spoke, Death himself appeared to him in the form of a skeleton wrapped in a dark cloak, asking the man if it was he who summoned him. Terrified, the man could only mutter in response: "Please, could you help me lift this bundle of sticks back onto my shoulders?"
fable2: A dog spent his days longing for freedom, dreaming of the day he could roam wherever he pleased. One morning, his owner left the front gate open and the dog seized his chance. He ran off into the woods, reveling in his newfound liberty. But as night fell, he grew hungry and cold with no food or shelter. How he wished to be back in his warm bed, with a full bowl of kibble. The dog returned home, tail between his legs, and never complained about his confinement again. He had learned that sometimes our dreams don't live up to reality.

fable1: A wealthy man was throwing a great feast for his friends and acquaintances. His dog took this opportunity to invite a friend of his own, a stray, to whom he promised plenty of food as there has always been a lot of leftovers on similar occasions in the past. The stray eagerly consented and showed up at the house at the appointed hour. As the two dogs walked through the corridors, the stray got more and more excited about all the food around him, promising himself to eat enough to last him several days, and wagging his tail in appreciation of his thoughtful friend. However, as soon as they reached the kitchen, a cook noticed the stray and, grabbing him by the legs, threw him out of the nearest window. Landing on the hard ground, the dog howled in pain and limped away from the house. Soon, he was approached by other strays who asked him about his visit to his wealthy friend. The stray replied: "To be honest, I donâ€™t remember all of the details. I drank so much wine, I donâ€™t even know how I got out of the house again!"
fable2: A sly fox snuck into a farmer's chicken coop through a hole in the back wall. He gobbled up three plump hens and was working on a fourth when the farmer burst in wielding a rake. The fox scrambled to escape out the back, but the farmer had sealed up the hole. Cornered, the fox pleaded for mercy, but the angry farmer would have none of it. He snatched up the fox and flung him out the window into the yard. The fox bounced as he hit the hard ground. Sore but alive, he slinked away, resolving never to try sneaking in the back way again.

fable1: During one of their regular gatherings, the animals of the forest entertained each other with song and dance. When it was his turn, the orangutan stood up and performed a beautiful and complex dance. The audience, dazzled, showered him in applause as he sat back down. The sloth, envious of the attention the orangutan was receiving and wanting it for himself, stood up and danced next. But, his movements were so ridiculous and uncoordinated that the other animals, offended by such mockery, attacked him and drove him out of their gathering.
fable2: The farm cat watched the humans sit down for dinner. They used forks and knives and napkins so fancy. The cat wanted to be like them, as cats do. So at his next meal, he grasped his fork awkwardly in his paw. He jabbed his knife at the mouse he was to eat. But his clumsy grip sent the utensils flying. His dinner ran off amidst the chaos. The cat was left with an empty plate. Moral: It is foolish to mimic those above you.

fable1: A hawk, hunting for dinner, attempted to ambush a snake that he saw crawling along a forest path. The snake noticed the hawk just in time, however, and trapped him in her coils. As the two fought for their respective lives, they were spotted by a woodsman walking along the same path. Without a second thought, he helped the hawk by freeing him from the snake who, in an act of revenge, spat some of her poison into the woodsmanâ€™s drinking horn before crawling away into the grass. As the man was about to quench his thirst after all the excitement, the hawk knocked his horn to the ground, spilling the poison within.
fable2: A hungry fox came across a flock of birds pecking at seeds on the ground. The fox crouched down, ready to pounce, when one little bird looked up and shouted "Fox! Run away!" All the other birds flew off in a hurry. The fox's stomach grumbled with disappointment. The next day, the little bird's wing was stuck in a thorn bush. The fox walked over and gently freed the bird's wing from the thorns. The bird chirped happily and flew away. From that day on, whenever the fox and the little bird crossed paths in the forest, they would give a friendly nod to each other.

fable1: A long time ago, all ducks and swans were able to sing beautiful songs. But, one day, they heard the neigh of a horse and fell so in love with its sound that they spent all of their time trying to imitate it. In their efforts, they eventually forgot their songs and have not managed to remember them to this day.
fable2: A contented farmer lived a simple life with his family on their small farm. Though they were poor, they valued the time spent together and the joy of each new day. One evening, a wandering merchant came to the farm and told fanciful stories of faraway cities paved in gold. The farmer became obsessed with finding this fortune. He abandoned his family and farm, traveling across oceans in search of the golden city. After years of fruitless seeking, tired and alone, he returned home. The farm had fallen into disrepair, his wife had remarried, his children grown. He realized too late that his desire for imaginary riches had cost him the true blessings of his former life.

fable1: A wild boar was rubbing her tusks against the trunk of a tree when a raccoon approached her. Seeing what the boar was doing, he asked: "Why are you sharpening your tasks? The hunting season has not yet started - there is no imminent danger to you." The boar replied: "I do this in preparation. There would be no time to sharpen them when I am being hunted."
fable2: The old farmer lived a quiet life tending to his fields each day. When the king declared war on the neighboring kingdom, all able-bodied men were summoned to battle. The farmer had not held a sword in many years. As he heard the trumpet blare, signaling the troops to assemble, he frantically searched for his rusted sword. He found it stuffed in the back of his barn and tried to sharpen the dull blade on a stone. But it was too late - the blade could not be made ready in time. As the farmer sadly walked to join the other soldiers, he realized he should have kept his sword maintained in preparation rather than waiting until it was needed.

fable1: A pelican swallowed a fish that was far too large for his throat and was slowly suffocating as he lay on the sea shore. Flying overhead, a falcon observed: "He got what he deserved. A bird is supposed to hunt in the air, not in the sea."
fable2: A curious fox was walking through the forest when he came upon a rabbit in a clearing. The rabbit was busily gathering carrots into a pile. The fox watched the rabbit work for a while, growing more and more tempted by the carrots. Finally, the fox could no longer resist and leapt out to snatch a carrot. The startled rabbit ran away, leaving his carrots behind. The fox happily munched on a carrot, but soon realized he had ruined the rabbit's hard work for a single bite. Ashamed, the fox resolved to only gather his own food from then on, rather than interfere with the business of others.

fable1: A young boy was tasked with herding a flock of sheep near a village. He quickly grew bored of watching the animals and, to amuse himself, shouted "Wolf! Wolf!", which caused all villagers to come running towards the flock to protect it. When they arrived, the boy only laughed at them for being so gullible. He repeated this several times until, one day, he actually saw a wolf stalking the flock. Despite his cries for help, none of the villagers arrived, as they were fed up with his pranks and no longer believed him. The wolf, facing little opposition, soon decimated the flock.
fable2: A fox was known throughout the forest as a dishonest trickster. One day, he came across a hunter's trap hidden on the path. When a rabbit hopped along, the fox warned him "Watch out! There is a trap ahead." The skeptical rabbit laughed and said "Nice try, fox, but I won't fall for your lies." He kept hopping and became ensnared in the trap. The fox just shook his head and walked away, leaving the rabbit struggling. Though the fox told the truth, the rabbit's distrust of him led to his downfall.

fable1: A crab was tired of living close to the sea and decided to move to the lush, green meadow as his new home. As he was settling in, a coyote discovered him crawling around in the grass and gobbled him up as an afternoon snack. Just before he was eaten, the crab said: " What else did I expect? After all, I traded the home that I was well-adapted to in my nature and habits for this patch of land."
fable2: A young fox lived in a small den at the edge of the forest. Though it was cramped, she had just enough room to sleep. The fox envied the rabbits in their roomy warrens and the birds in their lofty nests. One day she set out to find a bigger home. She searched the whole forest but found no empty dens. As the sun set, she returned to her tiny den, weary from her fruitless search. Curled up to sleep, she realized this small space was just right for her. The fox was content once more, for now she knew the value of what she had.

fable1: A man and a tiger were walking together through the forest, discussing the relative strengths of men and tigers to pass the time. Engaged in their debate, they happened across a statue depicting a tiger being subdued by a man. The traveller pointed at the statue and said: "See? Clearly men must be far stronger than tigers, like this statue shows." The tiger retorted: "If this statue had been made by tigers, and not by men, it would show a tiger clutching a man in his claws."
fable2: A fox was walking through the woods when he came upon a deer drinking from a stream. Seeing an opportunity for a meal, the fox crept towards the deer. Just as the fox prepared to pounce, a hunter emerged from the bushes, aiming his rifle at the deer. The deer bolted away before the hunter could fire. Frustrated, the hunter turned and left. The fox, who had been focused only on catching the deer, was startled to realize how close he had come to being shot himself. After that day, the fox was much more careful about assessing situations before acting.

fable1: A pair of coyotes, nearly dying of hunger, noticed several cowhides drying on the opposite side of a river. Unable to swim across the river due to their weakness, they decided to drink it dry and then walk to the other side. But, long before they were able to get to the hides, they burst after drinking too much of the water.
fable2: A young bird sat in her nest, gazing out at the open sky. She dreamed of soaring high above the trees and clouds. One day, she decided to try. She leapt from her nest and flapped her tiny wings with all her might. But she was too young, her wings too small. The ground rushed up to meet her. Her mother cried out but could not reach her in time. The little bird hit the ground with a soft thud. Some things are not possible, no matter how much we wish they were.

fable1: Two toads lived as neighbors not too far away from each other. But while one toad lived in a deep pond hidden away from the public by tall grass, the other inhabited a shallow puddle which was often disturbed by the wheels of passing carriages. The first toad tried several times to convince his neighbor to move in with him, but the latter refused, saying how difficult it would be for him to leave a place he has grown so used to. Soon, an especially heavy wagon passed through the puddle, catching the toad by surprise and squashing him under its wheels.
fable2: A hungry fox saw some ripe grapes hanging high on a vine. He jumped and stretched but could not reach them. He tried again and again, refusing to give up. Finally, exhausted from jumping, the fox said, "Those grapes are probably sour anyway." And he walked away, his hunger unsatisfied and his pride wounded. The grapes, just out of reach, remained as sweet as ever.

fable1: A tortoise, slowly crawling through the grass on a hot summerâ€™s day, called out to the birds flying overhead and asked if there was one among them who could teach her how to fly. A hawk heard her call and asked what he would get in return for taking her with him. The tortoise, eager to take to the skies, promised him all the riches of the Red Sea. The hawk agreed and carried the tortoise upwards in his talons. But, just as they reached the clouds, he suddenly let go of her and the tortoise fell towards the ground, eventually landing on the side of a mountain and shattering her shell. As she lay dying, the tortoise reflected that her fate was well-deserved: "Why did I dream of wings and clouds, when I can't even walk on the ground with ease?"
fable2: The peacock was known across the land for his beautiful, shimmering tail feathers. He loved to strut around and show them off to the other animals. One day a fierce storm rolled in. The peacock continued to strut proudly, fanning his feathers to impress the animals taking shelter. A strong gust of wind suddenly blew, ruffling the peacock's feathers. He squawked in horror as some of his radiant tail feathers were ripped out by the wind. The bedraggled peacock was left with a ragged, ugly tail. He retreated in shame, learning the hard way that vanity leaves one vulnerable to humiliation. From then on, the peacock was much humbler.

fable1: A queen bee once visited Zeus to offer him some of the fresh honey from her hive. Delighted by her delicious offering, Zeus promised to grant her a single wish. After some thinking, the bee asked Zeus to give her a sting, so that she could attack anyone who comes too close to the hive. This saddened Zeus as he did not wish to introduce a new source of danger for his beloved humans, but bound by his promise he could not refuse the request. Thus, he gave the bee a sting, but also made it so that stinging anyone would cost the bee her life, since the sting would remain firmly stuck in her opponent.
fable2: The fox was always scheming to catch the hen and her chicks. One day he had an idea. He told the hen that if she wished hard enough, she could make the moon fall from the sky. Eagerly, the hen closed her eyes and wished with all her might. The moon stayed in the sky, but the next morning, the fox snuck in and stole all her chicks. The hen wept bitterly at being tricked. She realized she should not have trusted the words of a cunning fox. Ever after, she was wary of believing claims that sounded too good to be true.

fable1: A donkey was once driven along a busy street, carrying a famous image of a saint, to be placed inside the townâ€™s main church. As he moved along, bystanders bowed deeply before the image and prayed in accordance with religious customs. The donkey, however, assumed that the bows and prayers were directed at him and, filled with pride, refused to take another step. His driver, bemused by the animalâ€™s behavior, hit him with the whip, saying how ridiculous it would be for men to pray to a donkey.
fable2: A group of mice lived in a farmer's barn. When the farmer's cat caught one of them, the others panicked. The head mouse proclaimed, "I will bell this cat so we can hear it coming." That night he tied a bell around the sleeping cat's neck. The next day when the cat failed to catch any mice, the head mouse boasted of his clever plan. Upon hearing this, the old mouse who had suggested the bell spoke up. "You may wear the bell, but the idea belongs to me." The others nodded in agreement. From then on, they made sure to properly credit good ideas, no matter who thought of them.

fable1: A young puppy used to sneak up on people and bite their feet. Due to his small size, he was difficult to notice and often caught people unawares. Thus, his master hung a chime around his neck, which would ring out with every step the puppy took. Not recognising its true purpose, the puppy grew proud of the chime and went to show it off around town. There, he encountered an older dog who said to him: "What are you doing? This chime of yours is not something to be proud of. On the contrary, it lets everyone know that you have been a bad dog."
fable2: The fox longed to be as well-known as the lion, the king of the jungle. He tried increasingly daring stunts to get the animals' attention, until one day he stole the lion's crown. The animals gasped and stared as the fox paraded around in the glittering crown. From that day on, whenever the animals saw the fox coming they would whisper "look, it's the thief!" The fox was delighted that the animals recognized him, though their gossip was not admiring. The more the animals gossiped, the bolder the fox's antics became. In the end, the fox had all the notoriety he desired, but not the respect and fame he had envied in the lion.

fable1: A fly landed on a ramâ€™s horn as he was grazing in a meadow and sat there for quite some time. As she was about to fly off, the fly asked the ram if he would like her to go or preferred that she stay longer. The ram replied: "I didnâ€™t notice when you arrived and I wonâ€™t miss you once youâ€™re gone."
fable2: The fox was walking through the forest one day when he came upon a flock of birds. "What simple creatures," he said to himself. "I am so much cleverer than they are." Just then he stepped into a hidden trap that snapped shut around his leg. The fox struggled to get free, but it was no use. The birds gathered around and chirped mockingly at the fox's predicament. That evening, the hunter returned and collected the fox from his trap. The birds watched from the trees, chuckling at how the cunning fox had been outwitted. Though he considered himself above the birds, in the end the fox was simply prey to the hunter.

fable1: Two roosters living in the same farmyard were fighting for dominance over the rest of the farm chickens. Eventually, one emerged as the victor. The defeated opponent scurried away and hid in the shadow of a tree, while the winner paraded around the yard, crowing and spreading his wings. This drew the attention of a hawk flying overhead, who quickly descended on the loud rooster and carried him off in his talons. Seeing this, his opponent came out of the shadows and became the undisputed ruler of the yard.
fable2: The lion was the king of the jungle. He strutted around proudly with his mane flowing. One day he spotted a porcupine. Amused, he approached to bat it around for fun. The porcupine did not back down. It raised its quills threateningly. Undeterred, the lion swatted at it. The porcupine stabbed the lion with dozens of quills. Howling in pain, the lion fled, having learned a painful lesson about pride.

fable1: Two oxen were dragging a heavily laden cart along a dusty country road. With every step the oxen took, the wheels of the wagon creaked in a strained and pitiful way. The oxen eventually turned around to address the wheels: "Dear wheels, why are you making such noise? After all, we are doing all of the work - if anyone should be complaining, itâ€™s us."
fable2: A mother bird built her nest high in a tree. She laid her eggs and cared for them each day. One windy afternoon, a big branch snapped and her nest fell to the ground. When she returned, she found her eggs smashed on the rocks below. The mother bird let out no cry. She gathered the broken shells in silence. She mourned alone, tending to her lost babies. The mother's heart was breaking, yet she suffered quietly. Her sadness was a private pain.

fable1: An old woman owned a single sheep and as the time came to shear him, she decided to do so herself to save some money. However, she was not skilled in this task and ended up shearing some of the sheepâ€™s flesh together with the fleece. In great pain, the sheep cried out: "What have I done to you to hurt me so, mistress? What value does my blood add to the wool? If you want my meat, take me to a butcher, as he at least will spare me unnecessary pain. But if you want my wool, take me to a shearer who knows his craft."
fable2: A young man inherited a small sum of money from his father. Eager to make the money grow, he invested it all in a new business selling bread. At first business was slow, and the young man struggled to turn a profit. After months of hard work baking bread each morning, the young man finally earned back his investment. Though it required great effort, the business succeeded and the young man expanded to sell baked goods throughout the town. In time, his bakery became the most successful shop in the area. The young man learned that dedicating time and effort leads to greater rewards than seeking quick returns.

fable1: A sick bull was lying in a quiet corner of the farmyard, unable to move. One by one, his companions stopped by to ask about his well-being and each one took some of the food that was left for the bull by his owner. Eventually, the bull died - not of his sickness but of hunger.
fable2: A young fox was eager to prove himself to the older foxes in his den. He met a cunning wolf who said he knew how they could steal food from a nearby farm. Excited, the fox agreed to help. That night they snuck onto the farm and stole chickens from the coop. The next morning, the farmer set traps around the coop to catch the thieves. The fox returned that night alone, driven by greed to steal more. But his paw was caught in a trap, leaving him howling in pain. The wolf was nowhere to be found as the farmer approached. The fox realized too late that his wicked partner had led him astray and abandoned him to his fate.

fable1: "Little shrub, why donâ€™t you do as I do and raise yourself up to the skies?", asked the oak of the shrub that was growing nearby. The shrub replied: "I am happy with the way I am. Besides, while you are certainly mightier than I can ever hope to be, I think that I am safer." The oak laughed at the word of the shrub: "Safer? who could possibly threaten me or throw me to the ground?" Shortly after, a strong storm visited the forest and uprooted the oak, felling it without much effort. The shrub, on the other hand, bent to the storm, and stood upright once it passed.
fable2: A timid field mouse lived quietly in a meadow. One day a hawk circled above looking for prey. The little mouse trembled in fear as the hawk's shadow passed over him. Thinking quickly, the mouse scurried under a fallen leaf and flattened himself against the ground. He held perfectly still as the hawk's talons passed just inches from his nose. After what seemed like an eternity, the mouse heard the hawk fly away unsatisfied. Still shaking, the mouse emerged from under the leaf and saw the hawk disappearing over the trees. From that day on, whenever the mouse went out to find food, he made sure to stay hidden in the tall grass. Though his view was obscured, the mouse felt safe from the dangers above.

fable1: One evening, a goatherd was driving his flock towards the farm and noticed that a couple of wild goats had joined the flock during the day. Happy about the newcomers, he led them into the enclosure with the rest of the goats and closed it overnight. Next day, the goats were unable to go to the pasture due to a heavy storm, so the goatherd supplied them with hay for the day, giving the wild goats plenty of food to entice them to stay, while only giving just enough to the rest of the flock. The day after, just as the goatherd opened the enclosure to bring the goats to the pasture, the wild goats stormed out and ran away as fast as they could. Upset, the goatherd shouted after them, accusing them of ingratitude. The goats replied: "The very reason why we do not want to stay is that you gave us more food than your own flock! If we stayed and some new goats came along, you would treat us badly just to impress the new arrivals."
fable2: The fox had been friends with the rabbit since they were young. One day a cunning wolf befriended the fox and invited him to hunt together. Excited to hunt with the powerful wolf, the fox agreed without hesitation. That night under the full moon, the fox followed the wolf through the woods until they came upon the rabbit's burrow. The trusting rabbit emerged, overjoyed to see his old friend. But the fox turned away as the wolf pounced, and the rabbit's cries faded into the darkness. From then on, the fox and wolf were inseparable, even as the fox was haunted by memories of who he left behind.

fable1: The lumberjack had felled an old redwood and, to split its trunk into pieces for transport, fashioned wedges from its branches. The redwood sighed with sadness - it was not as upset about having been felled, as it was about the fact that its own branches were used to break it apart.
fable2: A fox was prowling through the forest looking for his next meal. He spotted a rabbit and immediately gave chase. The rabbit darted away, fleeing for its life. In his haste, the fox did not see the thorny bushes up ahead. He crashed through them, yelping in pain as the thorns tore at his skin and fur. The rabbit escaped to safety, but the fox's own reckless actions had caused him injury. He limped home hungry and bleeding, regretting that he had brought this misfortune upon himself through his carelessness.

fable1: Having visited places all over the world, the traveller often bragged about different feats he performed during his travels upon his return to his hometown. Once, he claimed that he jumped so high into the air when visiting Tokyo that no other man could ever jump even half as high. To lend his words more credence, he followed up by saying that plenty of people in Tokyo could be called on as witnesses to his deed. One of the bystanders pointed out that this would not be necessary if the traveller just jumped right here in front of them, like he had done in Tokyo.
fable2: A young fox was prowling through the forest when he came upon a wise old owl perched in a tree. "Look at me!" the fox shouted. "I'm the sneakiest, most clever fox in the whole forest!" The owl said nothing and continued preening its feathers. The fox strutted and bragged some more. "I can outwit any creature here. No one is as fast or as cunning as me!" The owl blinked slowly and remained silent. Frustrated, the fox stomped off, muttering about the stupid owl. He set off to find someone else to impress with his boasts. The owl watched him go, then quietly returned to its nap, needing no words to prove its wisdom.

fable1: A hungry fox was stalking a rabbit one sunny afternoon. Seeing the rabbit's shadow on the ground, the fox pounced, snapping his jaws shut on empty air. Again and again he leapt at the dancing shadow, growing more frantic with each failed attempt. Meanwhile the rabbit, startled by the fox's first lunge, had run to safety in his burrow. As dusk fell, the fox collapsed, exhausted and empty-handed. The rabbit enjoyed a hearty meal in the comfort of his home, never realizing how close he had come to danger. The fox had wasted his day chasing an illusion and missed the true prize.
fable2: A badger, crossing a bridge over a river with a piece of meat in his teeth, saw his own reflection in the water and took it for that of another badger, with a piece of meat double his own in size. He immediately let go of his own, and attacked the other badger to get his larger piece. In the end, he lost both: that which he clawed at in the water, because it was a reflection; and his own, because the river swept it away.

fable1: A young fox lived in a forest that was experiencing a terrible drought. There was barely any food or water to be found. Desperate, the fox searched high and low for something to eat and drink. After days of struggle, she had an idea. Gathering sticks and stones, she built a dam on a small stream, creating a pool of water. She then fashioned a net from grass and used it to catch fish in her new pond. Thanks to her invention born of necessity, the fox survived the drought when others did not.
fable2: A magpie dying of thirst saw a jug, and hoping to find water, flew to it with haste. When she reached it, she discovered to her grief that it contained so little water that she could not reach it. She tried everything she could think of to reach the water, without success. At last she collected as many small rocks as she could carry and dropped them one by one with her beak into the jug, until she could reach the water and prevent her own death.

fable1: A fox decided to host a grand feast and invited all the animals in the forest. He prepared a huge variety of dishes to appeal to every guest's taste. The deer wanted salad, the bears wanted honey, the birds wanted seeds. But with so many options, none of the animals could agree on what to eat. Each one complained that the food wasn't quite right. The fox grew more and more distressed as he tried unsuccessfully to satisfy everyone. Finally the guests left, still hungry and grumbling. The fox vowed never again to waste such effort trying to please creatures with such different tastes.
fable2: A middle-aged man, whose hair had started graying, dated two women at the same time. One was younger, and the other older than him. The older woman, ashamed to be seen with a younger man, pulled out some of his black hairs whenever he came to visit. The younger, on the other hand, didnâ€™t want to become the wife of an older man, and removed every gray hair she could find. Thus he soon found himself without any hair left on his head.

fable1: A lazy fox spent his days sleeping in the shade of a tree instead of hunting for food. When winter came, he had not stored up enough to eat. His belly rumbled with hunger as he watched the diligent rabbits feast on their cache of carrots. The fox begged the rabbits for food, but they refused to share since he had not worked for it himself. Weak from lack of food, the fox was unable to hunt and eventually starved. The rabbits shook their heads, for they knew his laziness had led to his demise.
fable2: Two neighbours came before Zeus and asked him to grant them their wishes. Now, one of them was greedy, while the other was envious. To punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he asked for, but only if his neighbour had twice as much. The greedy one prayed to have a room full of gold. No sooner said than done; but all his joy turned to grief when he saw that his companion got two rooms filled with gold. The envious man didnâ€™t want his neighbor to have any joy at all and asked for one of his own eyes to be removed, so that his companion would go completely blind.

fable1: The fox came upon the rabbit nibbling carrots in the garden. "Those belong to me," said the fox. "I planted this garden myself." The rabbit continued eating. The fox repeated his claim more forcefully. The rabbit said nothing and kept eating. The fox shouted and demanded the rabbit stop. Still the rabbit silently ate. Enraged, the fox pounced on the rabbit and chased him from the garden. The patch was wrecked, carrots strewn everywhere.
fable2: Some storks chose a field newly sown with wheat as their new feeding ground. The owner of the field, for a while, scared them away by waving an empty sling. Once the storks found out that the sling was empty, they started to ignore the farmerâ€™s threats. In response, the farmer charged the sling with stones, killing dozens of the birds in quick succession.

fable1: It was a sunny day in the forest. A flock of blue jays were chirping loudly in the trees. Nearby, a murder of crows cawed raucously. The two groups kept their distance, not mixing with one another. Suddenly, a lost cardinal appeared, its red feathers bright amidst the blue and black birds. It flew to the jays, trying to join their flock. But the jays scolded the cardinal, chasing it away. Dejected, the cardinal flew to the crows instead. Though different in color, the crows accepted the cardinal, letting it roost among them.
fable2: A farmer covered his wheat field with nets in order to catch some of the storks who had been eating the freshly sown seeds. Among the storks, he also caught a robin, who broke his little leg. The robin asked the farmer to spare and release him. "Please let me go, as my broken limb is most pitiful and I am not a stork, but a robin - a good and honest bird. I love my father and mother and have a plumage quite unlike that of a stork." The farmer laughed at that, saying "This may all well be true, but I only know that I caught you together with the other thieves, and now you must perish together with them, as well."

fable1: A young dove wanted to find a mate. She let the flashy peacocks court her with gifts and flattery. The peacocks enjoyed her company but soon lost interest. The dove was heartbroken. She realized the peacocks never cared for who she truly was inside. They only wanted her beauty and attention. From then on, the dove was more discerning with her suitors. She waited patiently for a mate who cherished her character and spirit. In time, she found love with a kindhearted dove who saw her true worth.
fable2: The horse and the moose had a fight, so the horse went to the woodsman and asked him for help in getting back at the moose. The woodsman agreed, saying: "If you want my help, I will have to place this iron between your jaws to be able to guide you with these reins. I must also saddle you, so that I can keep steady as we pursue your enemy." The horse agreed and was quickly saddled and bridled. After the moose was vanquished, the horse demanded that the woodsman remove the riding equipment, to which the woodsman replied that he prefers to keep the horse just as he is.

fable1: A young fox worked hard to build a large, beautiful den at the base of a hill. The other animals admired his fine home and came often to visit. When a great storm flooded the valley, the fox's den was destroyed. The fox had no place to stay and little food to eat. His friends, who he had entertained in good times, welcomed the fox into their homes and shared their food until he could rebuild. Though the fox had lost much, he knew with good friends, he would endure this trial.
fable2: A magpie, dying of illness, asked her father: "Father, do not mourn my death, but instead ask the gods to save me." He replied, "Which of the gods do you think will come to your aid? Is there one among them whose altar you havenâ€™t stolen shiny offerings from?"

fable1: A fox was hungry and wanted to eat the grapes in a vineyard. He jumped and jumped but could not reach them. Angry, the fox said "Those grapes are probably sour anyway!" He walked away, still hungry. In truth, the grapes were ripe and sweet. The fox had only fooled himself into thinking they were no good. His lies did not change how good the grapes were, only his opinion of them. All the fox achieved by lying was to stay hungry.
fable2: An ape, after surviving a shipwreck, encountered a turtle who offered to carry him to the shore. To pass the time, the ape told the turtle many fantastical stories, each of them filled with lies and exaggerations.  "I see you have quite the education ", said the turtle,  "unlike me, who didnâ€™t have much schooling." As the two entered a bay, the turtle asked the ape if he knew Herring Roads, by which the bay was commonly known. The ape thought the turtle meant a famous man and, not wishing to appear ignorant, said:  "Of course I know Rhoades - he is a old college friend of mine, who also happens to be my - " The turtle couldnâ€™t bear to hear any more lies and dove quickly underwater, causing the ape to vanish forever.

fable1: A fox was walking through the forest one day when he came across a bunch of ripe, juicy grapes hanging from a vine. He eagerly jumped up to grab them, but they were too high up. The fox tried again and again, but he just couldn't reach the grapes. Frustrated, he gave up and said to himself "Those grapes are probably sour anyway." And with that, he continued on his way, his stomach still empty. The grapes, in fact, were as sweet and delicious as they looked. But the fox's false tale of their sourness kept him from the truth.
fable2: A raccoon and an ape were travelling together along the same road. On their way, they passed through a cemetery full of statues. "All these statues," said the ape, "are made to honor my ancestors, who achieved great things in their day." The raccoon replied, "You have picked a most appropriate subject for your lies, as it would be difficult for any of your ancestors to disagree with your words."

fable1: A mother hen gathered her chicks and said "Children, you must always wake at dawn to search for food." But the next morning, the chicks slept in as the mother hen herself had not risen. When the mother realized her mistake, she got up early the next day, scratching and pecking at the ground. Seeing her, the chicks also woke early and followed her lead in looking for worms. From then on, the chicks woke at first light without their mother saying a word. Her actions spoke louder than instructions, demonstrating that example can be more powerful than precept.
fable2: A crab said to his daughter, "Child, why do you always walk so one-sided? It is far better to go straight forward." To which the daughter replied: "This may be so, father - why donâ€™t you show me how itâ€™s done and Iâ€™ll follow in your footsteps?" The father-crab tried and failed repeatedly, finally admitting to his daughter that he canâ€™t do it himself.

fable1: A farmer worked hard tending his fields through the long summer. When fall came, he harvested all his crops and stored them safely away. Winter brought bitter cold and deep snow. Many animals came to the farm seeking food and shelter to survive. Though the farmer wanted to help, he knew he must save enough to feed his family. When spring returned, bringing mild weather and new growth, the farmer opened his storehouse. He shared the remaining grain and produce so all the creatures could thrive again. The farmer was glad he had waited for the right season to offer aid.
fable2: An angler, who was also a skilled musician, took his nets and his flute to the shore. There, he played a small concert for the fish, hoping that the music would compel them to dance into his nets that he laid below him in the water. After waiting for some time, he gave up and cast the nets into the sea, instead, catching plenty of fish in the process.

fable1: A young bird lived in a small nest with his family. He dreamed of flying high up to the clouds. One day, he left his nest and tried to fly up towards the sky. But his wings were too small and weak. He struggled and flapped as hard as he could, but began falling down fast. Luckily his mother swooped down and caught him, bringing him safely back to the nest. Though disappointed, the young bird was grateful for his mother's love. He realized he was not yet ready to fly so high. From then on, he contented himself with short flights close to home.
fable2: A man had a donkey and a small Pomeranian dog. The donkey lived in a stable with plenty of oats and hay, but spent his days working at the mill and carrying heavy loads of wood from the forest to the farm. The Pomeranian, on the other hand, knew many tricks and was fondled by his master, who always gave him tasty treats. The donkey envied the life of the Pomeranian and one day decided to make his way into the masterâ€™s house, imitating the Pomeranianâ€™s tricks as best as he could. In doing so, he broke the masterâ€™s table and smashed his precious dishes to pieces. Seeing this, the servants quickly drove the donkey back into the stable, kicking and beating him with clubs all the way, nearly killing him.

fable1: A young bird fell from its nest before it could fly. It called out for its mother to come rescue it. But she did not appear. So the little bird flapped its wings as hard as it could. At first it only managed to hop a few inches off the ground. But it kept trying over and over. With more effort each time, the bird was soon able to take short flights. Before long, it was flying high up into the trees. Though its mother never came, the little bird learned to fly on its own.
fable2: A snipe had made her nest in the early spring on a recently sown wheat field. Her children have almost grown to their full size, when the owner of the field, looking over his by then ripened crop, said, "I will ask all my friends and neighbors to help me with the harvest." One of the young snipes asked his mother whether they should move to a new place for safety. "Not yet," she replied; "a man who only asks his friends to help him with the harvest does not have his mind fully set to it." A few days the farmer noticed the wheat to be heavy with grain and proclaimed: "Tomorrow, I will hire as many labourers as I can and harvest this wheat myself." Upon hearing these words, the snipe said to her children, "It is time for us to move -  a man who no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself, will go through with his plans."

fable1: The fox and the rabbit were enemies who lived in the same forest. One day, the cunning fox promised the rabbit that if he came to the fox's den, no harm would come to him. Trusting the fox's promise, the naive rabbit visited the fox's den, only to be captured and eaten. The other animals shook their heads, knowing that the fox had broken his false promise, as foxes and rabbits were natural enemies. From then on, the remaining animals were wary of believing any promises made by an enemy.
fable2: "Be quiet." said the nanny to the infant on her lap. "If you donâ€™t stop crying at once, I will give you to the coyote who will gobble you up." As it happened, a coyote passed by the window at just this moment. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited until at last the infant began to cry again. Then, the coyote came forward before the window, and looked up to the nanny, wagging his tail in anticipation of his meal. But the nanny quickly shut down the window and called for help, so that the coyote ended up being chased away by dogs.

fable1: A lion grew bored of hunting the same zebra herd day after day. He decided to befriend the zebras and learn their ways. At first, the lion was fascinated by the zebras' routines and habits. But as time went on, the zebras' mundane lives began to seem dull to the lion. Soon, the lion started mocking the zebras for being so boring and predictable. The zebras were hurt by the lion's scornful words. One day, the lion laughed as a zebra tripped and fell. That was the last straw for the zebras, who decided to find a new home far away from the contemptuous lion. Though lonely at first, the lion was relieved to resume the thrilling hunt.
fable2: When first the raccoon encountered the tiger he was very frightened, so he ran away and hid himself in the woods. Next time, however, he came near the tiger, but stopped at a safe distance, watching the majestic beast pass him by. The third time they came near one another the raccoon went right up to the tiger, asking him how his family were, and when they may come across each other again. Once their conversation was concluded, he parted from the tiger without much ceremony or reverence.

fable1: The fox preached to the hens about the importance of trust and community. He spoke at length about how they must watch over each other and be vigilant against deception. The hens clucked in agreement, moved by his wise words. But when the fox invited them to a feast to celebrate their new friendship, the hens declined. They recognized the hypocrisy of the fox who had often tried to eat them before. Though his speeches proclaimed harmony, his true nature was laid bare by his past actions. And so the hens kept their distance, for they knew fine words were not the same as a good heart.
fable2: After being hunted down and wounded by a pack of dogs, the coyote lay sick and injured in his lair. Starving, he called to a goat who was passing by, begging him to get some water from a stream flowing nearby. "If you will bring me the water, I will be able to get myself some meat to help me recover.", the coyote said. "Yes," said the goat, "if I provide you with the water, Iâ€™m sure I will be the one providing you with the meat, as well."

fable1: A fox was walking through the forest when he came upon a porcupine. "Those quills look useful, may I have some?" the fox asked. The porcupine, wanting to be helpful, plucked some quills from his back and gave them to the fox. "Why thank you!" said the fox. He carefully took the quills in his mouth and left. Later that day, the porcupine was searching for food when the fox reappeared. Before the porcupine could react, the fox swiftly stabbed him with his own quills. The porcupine perished, realizing too late that he had made a grave mistake in arming his cunning enemy.
fable2: A woodsman came into a forest, asking the trees there for a new ax handle. Agreeing to his request, the trees offered him a young birch. Having fitted the new handle, the woodsman quickly felled the largest trees in the forest. An old oak, realizing too late their mistake, commented: "Had we not given up the birch so easily, we could have continued standing here for ages."

fable1: The fox loved to play tricks on his friend the rabbit. One day, the fox replaced the rabbit's carrot with a fake plastic one. The rabbit bit into the plastic and was quite upset. Later that day, the rabbit filled the fox's den with leaves while he was away. When the fox returned, he was buried in leaves up to his neck! The fox realized he deserved this joke after the trick he pulled on the rabbit. From then on, the two friends played less tricks and shared more laughs together.
fable2: An elderly woman who lost sight in both of her eyes called a doctor, agreeing that if he cures her blindness, he would receive a generous payment; but should his treatment fail then he would get nothing. The doctor visited the woman several times, applying a healing salve to her eyes and stealing a little of her valuables on each visit. Once he took everything of value, he healed her and asked to be paid. The woman refused, having noticed that her valuables are missing. Angered, the doctor summoned the woman before a judge, where she argued: " It is true that I promised to pay the doctor once I recover my sight. He now declares that I am healed, but I claim that I remain blind. You see, before I lost my sight, I saw in my house various valuable items: but now, although the doctor claims to have cured me, I see none of my prized possessions."

fable1: A young fox was searching for food in the forest when he came across a hungry wolf. "My friend, I know where you can find a plump, slow chicken to eat," said the wolf. Eager to fill his empty stomach, the fox trusted the wolf and followed him through the trees. Soon they arrived at a small farm, where the wolf led the fox straight into a trap. The fox was caught and the farmer came to take him away. As the wolf watched from the bushes, he laughed, for his advice had removed his competition for food. Though the fox struggled, he could not escape. From then on, the fox was wary of advice, especially when it came from those with an interest of their own.
fable2: A raccoon caught his tail in a trap, losing all of it but the stump in an effort to free himself. At first he was ashamed to face his kind, but then decided to embrace his fate. He summoned all the raccoons to a meeting, where he proposed that they should all remove their tails, as they were an inconvenience, making it harder to sit comfortably or run away from dogs. There was no advantage at all to having a tail, he argued.  "That is a nice speech," said one of the older raccoons; "but I doubt that you would make the same bold proposal if you still had your tail."

fable1: The young lion was eager to prove himself and challenge the alpha male. Though smaller and less experienced, he puffed out his chest and roared as loud as he could. The older lion did not respond with aggression. Instead he calmly sat down and groomed himself, ignoring the young challenger. The young lion roared louder and approached closer, but still the alpha male did not react with anger. Finally, frustrated and exhausted, the young lion gave up his futile attempt to intimidate and conceded defeat. With maturity, he realized that sometimes wisdom lies in stooping to conquer.
fable2: A huge tree was felled by the wind and thrown across a river. It fell among some weeds and asked them: "How are you, despite being so light and weak, not completely crushed by these strong winds?" The weeds replied, "You fight the wind, and are destroyed for that very reason; we bend before it and escape undamaged."

fable1: A fox came upon a hedgehog walking through the forest. "Let's be friends!" said the fox. The hedgehog was unsure whether he could trust the fox's intentions. Each day the fox invited the hedgehog to walk together, but the hedgehog always declined. Though the fox spoke kindly, the hedgehog sensed deception behind his words. One day the fox grew impatient and sprang at the hedgehog, who quickly curled into a ball, causing the fox's snout to be pricked by his quills. The fox learned that the untrusting hedgehog had been wise to keep his distance all along. From then on, the hedgehog walked alone, for he knew they could never truly be friends.
fable2: A coyote spotted a rabbit on the hillside and ran after her for some time. As he closed in on the rabbit, he would sometimes bite her as if intending to kill her, and playfully fawn at her at other times. Finally, the rabbit told the koyote: "I wish that you would show your true colors. Why do you bite me with such force, if you are my friend? And if you are my enemy, why do you fawn at me?

fable1: A fox spied a juicy grape vine hanging high on a trellis. He jumped and swiped at the grapes, but they were just out of reach. He jumped higher, straining his legs, but still could not reach the grapes. Again and again he leapt, refusing to give up. Finally, exhausted from overexertion, the fox collapsed beneath the trellis. As he lay there panting, the grapes he had so desired now hung above him, untouched and unreachable. With a frustrated sigh, the tired fox slunk away, grapes still dangling temptingly overhead.
fable2: One day a farmer found a huge, yellow egg next to one of his ducks that was as heavy as led. Assuming that someone was playing a trick on him, he initially wanted to throw it away. But he decided to take it home with him, after all, and soon realized that it was made of pure gold. He found a new egg every morning and soon became very rich by selling them. The richer he got, the more greedy he became, until he finally decided to get all the gold at once by killing the responsible duck. But, having killed and opened her, he found nothing inside.
